Gotcha. Yeah, looks like it's something with the underlying OS. Hopefully they can fix the bug :)

On non windows machines what drive would you expect a USB stick to be. On Windows you have C: D: E:  But (showing my windows-centricity here) you don't get a new drive letter  / filesystem, the usb mounts into the existing / file system . So it is left to you to create and name a drive pointing somewhere in the existing FS.

Hm, I would expect that it shows precisely the same (from conceptual point of view) as on Windows - a path to the drive - in my case on Mac /Volume/Pulec on Windows E:\\
Then I can use it for  `Set-Location` to be there.

A drive name can't contain   ; ~ / \ . : 
So you couldn't have a drive named /volume/Pulec. 
On Windows you have have multiple file systems which don't (by default) mount into one unifying one (hence they begin with A: B: C:  etc.). PowerShell doesn't _create_ a drive named "E", it recognizes "E" as a system drive.  If you connect Z: to \\localhost\c$  outside PowerShell, it shows up as a PS drive. PS Drives is Aliases + Environment + Functions + Variables + filesystems known to the OS +  Windows' Registry + Certificates + WSMAN
On Unix-derived OSes there is one unified fs in which other file systems mount. Because there isn't a new file system root there is no drive to add. You can make a Windows style drive (so in WSL I can create a PS drive 'C' for /mnt/c ) or one can make a short name for a mounted USB.  But there wouldn't be much point in in creating a psdrive Volume_Pulec in order to allow `set-Location volume_pulec: ` instead of `set-Location /volume/pulec `

You know, I would welcome a parity between Windows and MacOS and Linux behaviour and ability to use a generic way how to recognise that there is a new drive or portable media attached.

@scaleoutsean 

That's expected behaviour.  The Term "Drive" is inherited from  windows as analogous to "root-of-a-[pseudo]-file-system" 
Your filesystems on those disks are mounted into part of the / "drive",  they aren't roots in their own right as they would normally be on Windows.     

You **can** create new drives for places in the /  tree   for example
`New-PSDrive -Name C -PSProvider FileSystem -Root /mnt/c`  
Would present a C: drive on pwsh if that is a more convenient way to work.  But that is in addition to where the OS places them - on Linux system you'd expect to find them mounted somewhere under / wouldn't you ? And native Linux tools would probably demand you use the path from / not a C: style one.
